positive.review:
Okay I was being stupid at first. I thought this whole “frame generation” thing was just a gimmick that adds fake frames and makes your game have some input lag. I always preferred boosting FPS by lowering graphic settings.

But after seeing a YouTube video showcasing how lossless scaling performs on the steam deck, I decided to give it a try. And holyyy, it works really well. Back then, whenever I played some triple-A games on my deck, my FPS is consistently between 32 to 45, and now it went over 70 in some demanding games after i set it to 2X multiplier on LSFG-VK, and its still feels responsive. It makes me feel stupid for being ignorant here.

Later on, before I purchased this product, I learned that lossless scaling is using a mathematical-based frame method, not an AI-based method like NVIDIA DLSS. So i guess thats why it performs great on steam deck, because lossless scaling is based on math formulas to create extra frames, and not having a neural network/thinking like an AI, so it doesnt make the device work too hard.

Also, thing works great on steamOS, and its super easy to set up. As a steam deck user, Im really impressed.

Big thanks to Valve and the devs behind this tool!!!

Okay, imagine your Steam Deck calls up a tiny, hyperactive circus ringmaster, that’s Lossless Scaling. This app sneaks in like a sneaky jester and says, ‘You want more frames? Hold my popcorn,’ then uses its LSFG magic to conjure up extra frames out of thin air. Suddenly, your 30 FPS feels like it’s taken a double espresso and hit 60 or more. But yes, it’s not all unicorns riding rainbows you do pay a price: a dash of input lag, and sometimes things go a little wibbly-wobbly. On the Deck, it kinda works via community plugins (lsfg-vk), but you’ll need to baby-sit the settings because if the gremlin goes overboard, your gameplay can feel dreamy and sluggish instead of slick. Still, for the price (~$7) and the boost it gives, it’s like hiring a tiny frame-making clown who steals your latency but makes your games so much smoother

I have a top of the line gaming PC with a very beefy nvidia gpu and even then Lossless Scaling has turned into one of the most useful tools in my library especially when it comes to single-player games and emulation.(yes i dont have a alot of time on it but its testing for this review)

What really surprised me, though, is how much value it adds even when brute-force hardware isn't the limiting factor. Many single-player titles, especially older or poorly optimized ones, just don't support modern frame-generation tech, no matter how powerful your system is. Lossless Scaling fills that gap perfectly. Turning on frame generation through LS instantly makes these games feel smoother and more responsive while keeping the original look intact.

And that's not all for emulation it's equally impressive. Even on really high-end hardware a lot of classic games are locked to low framerates or have odd aspect ratios. LS handles it with ease-integer scaling looks incredibly clean, and adding extra smoothness to old titles makes them feel surprisingly modern without losing any of their charm.

I love the simplicity most of all launch a game toggle LS, and enjoy a much smoother experience. It's lightweight, stable, and works across a huge range of titles that would otherwise be stuck with dated limitations.

Assuming you have powerful hardware and want to get the most value from single-player games ones, in particular without native frame generation anyway Lossless Scaling is definitely worth the investment.

Short Review: Why would you pay 600-100 dollars for fake frames when you can just download fps for 7dollars??????

Long Review: I am utterly amazed. Such an incredible app. 
I have a 1080ti, been using it for years and years... Since the announcement of driver support coming to its end for 10x nvidia cards, I thought I should slowly start building a new pc. However, the prices... as well as the ram prices going up, a pc to my liking costs around 2.500 dollars in my country, which is 4-5 months of the avarage wage (simply not paying rent or even buying food) which is basically impossible to build a strong PC that would last for at least 5 years (and we also do not really know what kind of technologies or video games we will have in the future so it might even die faster or might last longer). Which made me think to find other ways to simply have more FPS.

First, I downloaded Opti Scaler (another amazing tool to get). That makes your games use DLSS / FSR4 without your card having it. However, it is still new and not supported in most games and in multiplayer titles... Well... you might get banned (as far as I know the anti-cheat system flags the tool as it plays with the in game files or whatever was not really knowledable about that part but the creator of the tool heavily warns the users about it.

Then, I tried NIS (image scaling) from Nvidia driver. Yes, it was good at first but the images were blurry, it did give me 144fps (my native hz for my monitor resolution). Without any latency forever, but the image quality was same as my eye vision in real life. And, well, I do not want to worsen it even more to be honest :D

So, I thought to myself, maybe there could be other ways and I remembered this yellow duck app :D Lossless Scaling. And, wanted to give it a try, it's simply 7 dollars? Why not, right?
And, it is simply amazing...

I have a 2K monitor running games at 2K. With all the new gen games, my FPS is normally in between 30-60 FPS everything on ultra / high. 
With this app settings LSFG 3.1, multiplier 2, scaling type FSR with 1 latency. My fps, simply, "downloading" 60 more fps. Whatever fps I had, it just simply doubles it.

I used to have concerns about the Latency / Artifacts / Lag or whatever etc,
Simply no, I have never seen an artifact nor latency was noticable. Like, barely even noticable. HOWEVER, I do use the app for singleplayer games and for multiplayer games you will feel the latency, I have played cs for 3k hours and chivalry 2 for 1k so I can safely say that you will feel it slightly but not that terrible. My nvidia app shows 0 MS latency for the game.

A 2nd strategy to have even MORE FPS: Optiscaler. I have combined Lossless Scaling with Optiscaler and well... I can get 20 to 50fps even more. 
I could write more about how nice this app is, and I am definitely looking forward to do more tweaks with this and try it out even more.

Games I have tried goes like this: Total War / Warhammer titles / Dying Light 2 / No rest For the Wicked. 

What makes Lossless Scaling even better?
Even an older title like Medieval 2, with Tsardoms mods and bunch of Reshade options, game hits 40-50 fps in battles and with Lossless scaling, my fps is around 80-90, game is a lot more smooth and no visible problems either. And the latency is barely noticable. 
And, this is what makes Lossless Scaling even better, for example, Opti scaler is an amazing app, but it can only support new games as old titles don't have DLSS or FSR settings.

Alright I've done extensive testing on all different types of games. And let me tell you, this is magic. Weirdly enough, it actually works. I honestly didn't think it would make a difference. It takes some getting used to, theres alot of setting that, if you don't know what you're doing can mess up some things (as in not "feel well", or make the game artifact like crazy).

As I mentioned, I've tested this on many games; BF6, Arc Raiders, Minecraft, Hogwarts Legacy, Cyberpunk 2077, Tarkov, FF XIV, WoW. And keep this in mind. They all behave differently to LS Framegen. I don't dabble in the scaling. Not my jam, but the framegen is where this app's bread and butter is made. 

Hogwarts Legacy, on High graphics, I get ~75 natively. I cap it to 60, triple my frames with LS and I can see 180 fps on my panel. A truly spectacle sight. It looks, and FEELS amazing. Thats the important part. And game can look smooth. But if it doesn't feel correct, its unplayable. Im referring to input latency. Theres gonna be input latency at all times. You're generating frames from basically an algorithm from my understanding. So your computer has to essentially guess where the things are gonna be. And yes, there will be artifacting, as in the UI jumbles around a bit. But with the settings, you can make the artifacting and input latency very minor.

I've played BF6, and it runs quite well. I can hit some crazy runs in a helo, or go boots on ground and run my M4 and still kill with no issue. MMORPGs looks spectacular as well. It baffles me how I can run framegen and actually see 144+ frames reliably on most games, and tweak the settings to make it feel better/look better. 

Now, it did not run well on Cyberpunk. The input latecy was too great for my liking. But it was one of my first tests, so if I tried it again Im sure I could fix some of it but I digress. And in comparison, Hogwarts Legacy runs a solid 180 fps with no input latency and minimal artifacting. Its wild. Arc Raiders runs like a dream as well. It truly lets you appreciate the game better when you're able to see the frames on your high hertz panel.

All in all, this is a crazy good app. Took a bit of getting used to of course, but once I started getting the hang of it, almost every game I've testing it on works well. But your experience may vary.

Here are my basic settings for most games
*** IF YOURE ON WINDOWS 11*** Capture API is WGC. The other one will break the app when you go to use it. 
Queue Target 1 (0 if you want less input latency)
Sync mode, OFF
Max Frame Latency 1 - 5 depending on the game *Higher number affects latency)
HDR support OFF (You may wanna have this on if you're running HDR)
GSYNC Support ON
Draw FPS ON
*Framegen* LSFG 3.1
Mode Fixed (Adaptive has had mixed results imo)
Multiplier (This is important. This is the number it will multiply your frames. If you're getting 60 FPS and you put 2 here, it'll render 120. You can put decimals, like 1.5 for example and get 90)
Flow Scale (This varies by game. From my experience this handles the artifacting. Further left, more artifacting, less latency if only a minor difference. Further right, less artifacting, but a bit more latency. Take into account your monitor's resolution. 1440p recommends 75, but I've played around with this alot. Its personal preference imo)
Performance On or Off depending on your computer. I have it On, Less latency, and I don't notice a visual difference with it Off
Multi-display mode ON.

I'm happy to change my review to a positive one if someone can point out what I'm missing to make this so called "amazing" software do it's thing. I'll admit, I've only tried this on one modern game - Arma Reforger, but after endless tweaking and tuning, LS has given me subpar results. I read on several forums and watched several videos claiming that Lossless Scaling can achieve amazing results on Arma games. Before I attempted this on my Arma, I googled dozens of people's preferred LS settings for Arma and came to a fairly common configuration that many claimed worked well. 

For background on my GPU, I have an nVidia RTX 4070 Ti, so out of the gates, it's no slouch of a GPU and it already achieves silky smooth 49-68 FPS natively in Arma at 3440 x 1440 resolution with most settings on ultra. 

In my every attempt to upscale Arma's performance, my LS generated FPS got worse and stuttered horrifically rather than got any smoother. I tried Arma in both Borderless Fullscreen, and Windowed mode with locked FPS in-game. 

The generated FPS in borderless fullscreen mode barely made an improvement with a base FPS of about 47-60 and a generated FPS of about 58-65, but the actual look and feel of LS's generative FPS was WAY worse than what genuine 65 FPS feels like. The generated FPS always appeared stuttery and sluggish versus my already silky smooth native FPS, no matter the LS settings I used. I should note that I capped the games FPS to 60 (half my monitors Hz as advised) and this was running at a resolution of 3440 x 1440. 

Windowed mode was an improvement, and I got a generated FPS of about 110 off a base FPS of 47-60. That said, this was very deceiving, because for some unknown reason Arma's windowed resolution restricted the game to a lousy 2560 x 1080 maximum despite my monitors native resolution being 3440 x 1440. If I'm running Arma natively at 2560 x 1080 resolution, my GPU achieves similar native results of around 100+ FPS to LS, so despite the fact that LS is showing my base and gen FPS as stated above, I'm not 100% sure I can trust it, because I know my GPU can deliver that FPS at those resolutions natively. 

Anyway, I'm not a hater of the app, I'm happy to be convinced otherwise and change my review accordingly. Please show me what I'm doing wrong! I'm just confused as to why so many positive reviews say how quickly and easily LS improves their FPS, on both old and new gen hardware and games, yet I can't even get one game to show remotely better results.

You can't have an FPS cap if you use an AMD GPU. LS totally ignores what you have set in AMD Adrenaline. In Adrenaline there is just a global option for FPS cap and not individual for every game/app that I think is possible with Nvidia GPU's. VSync combined with lowering the refresh rate to your desired max fps is the only option but then it is a fixed FPS, which is not a solution if your GPU can't keep the game constantly at e.g. 90 fps. The only "solution" I've found is using another third party software such as RTSS, but that is a workaround, not a solution. If FPS cap worked I would absolutely recommend LS, but now it is just useless to me. Have requested a refund.

I have been suggested to use this Lossless Scaling (LS) to improve my gaming experience.

I know this software is not that expensive, but I still tried to do some research by watching some Tech Youtuber about it.


My Conclusions :

1. To use this tool, as Linus (from LTT Youtuber) suggest, you need some spare GPU power to run it properly.

He mentioned, keep the GPU utilization below 85%.


2. I mostly play FPS and RTS, so good reaction time is a must. And as a lot of people has been saying LS is not good for competitive gaming, and it's true.

For example, my poor laptop (AMD 6600H, 16GB RAM dual channel), when running PUBG without LS can run about 45-50 FPS. However when LS is turned out, it's original FPS drop to 25 FPS, but the apparent FPS, after using LS' LSFG 3.1 adaptive to 75 FPS, appear to be 75 FPS.

But your actual input is still "connected" to that low 25 FPS, hence the lags when moving around.


3. Contradictorily, if your GPU have spare power to run LS properly, then it's actually have enough power to push higher FPS without LS ? So it's kinda in unusual situation, unless like what Linus did : using 2nd older GPU to run LS dedicatedly.

Again, contradictorily, if you do have spare GPU, you should sell it in the first place, then buy a better GPU rather than your current one.


4. But in those reviews from Youtuber I saw, there is other uses that I haven't tried. For example, it's supposedly could also make old retro / emulation games looks much better.
But I don't do Retro / Emulation, so I can't vouch for it.


In the end, if you play FPS, especially multiplayer, don't buy this thing. But since it's rather cheap, you could have fun tweaking with it, and support indie developer.

I have been suggested to use this Lossless Scaling (LS) to improve my gaming experience.

I know this software is not that expensive, but I still tried to do some research by watching some Tech Youtuber about it.


My Conclusions :

1. To use this tool, as Linus (from LTT Youtuber) suggest, you need some spare GPU power to run it properly.

He mentioned, keep the GPU utilization below 85%.


2. I mostly play FPS and RTS, so good reaction time is a must. And as a lot of people has been saying LS is not good for competitive gaming, and it's true.

For example, my poor laptop (AMD 6600H, 16GB RAM dual channel), when running PUBG without LS can run about 45-50 FPS. However when LS is turned out, it's original FPS drop to 25 FPS, but the apparent FPS, after using LS' LSFG 3.1 adaptive to 75 FPS, appear to be 75 FPS.

But your actual input is still "connected" to that low 25 FPS, hence the lags when moving around.


3. Contradictorily, if your GPU have spare power to run LS properly, then it's actually have enough power to push higher FPS without LS ? So it's kinda in unusual situation, unless like what Linus did : using 2nd older GPU to run LS dedicatedly.

Again, contradictorily, if you do have spare GPU, you should sell it in the first place, then buy a better GPU rather than your current one.


4. But in those reviews from Youtuber I saw, there is other uses that I haven't tried. For example, it's supposedly could also make old retro / emulation games looks much better.
But I don't do Retro / Emulation, so I can't vouch for it.


In the end, if you play FPS, especially multiplayer, don't buy this thing. But since it's rather cheap, you could have fun tweaking with it, and support indie developer.
